provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to principals, relevant employees, and successor entities within 5 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from recipients within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after Order entry, notify the Commission of structural or contact changes within 14 days for 10 years, notify of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all required reports by email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create certain records for 10 years after Order entry and retain each such record for 5 years, including all compliance records, consumer complaints and responses, and copies of all forms or screens through which personal information is collected from children.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through document requests, depositions, discovery, direct communications, employee interviews, and all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a), and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant and related parties are permanently enjoined from violating COPPA requirements, including failing to provide parental notice, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, failing to delete children's information upon parental request, and retaining children's data longer than necessary.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Children's Personal Information Previously Collected
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all Personal Information associated with Fortnite users as of the Compliance Date (unless exceptions apply) and submit a sworn written statement to the Commission confirming the deletions and describing any retained information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Default Privacy Settings for Children and Teens
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disclosing or enabling disclosure of a Child's or Teen's Covered Information to other users, or enabling a Child or Teen to converse with other users, unless the applicable parent or Teen has provided Affirmative Express Consent through an easily-located Privacy Setting.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Each Covered Business must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written Privacy Program that includes risk assessments, safeguards, employee training, service provider oversight, and annual evaluations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial assessments of its Privacy Program from a qualified, independent third-party Assessor approved by the FTC's Associate Director for Enforcement, and submit or retain those assessments as specified.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Privacy Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset access, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Starting one year after the Compliance Date and each year thereafter for ten years, Defendant must submit annual certifications from the Principal Executive Officer and senior officers of each Covered Business confirming compliance with the Order and disclosing any known material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Judgment of $275,000,000 is entered against Defendant as a civil penalty; Defendant must pay the full amount to the United States Treasury within seven days of Order entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must acknowledge receipt of the Order, deliver copies to relevant personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must file a compliance report one year after Order entry, submit notices of material changes within 14 days for ten years, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specific records for designated periods, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through information requests, depositions, document production, direct communications, employee interviews, and other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Prohibition on Disclosure of Health Information for Advertising Purposes
provisions.summary: Defendant and its officers, agents, employees, and attorneys are permanently restrained from disclosing Health Information to Third Parties for Advertising Purposes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant must not misrepresent its privacy and data practices, including representations about whether it shares health information with third parties, its compliance with the Digital Advertising Alliance principles, and whether consumers' health information is protected under HIPAA.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Prohibition on Disclosures Without Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Defendant must not disclose Health Information or PHR Identifiable Health Information to Third Parties for Non-Advertising Purposes without first obtaining Affirmative Express Consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Breach Notification and Notice Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant must notify affected users, the FTC, and media outlets of any Covered Incident within specified timeframes and provide required notice content, and must delete noted information upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program that protects the privacy and confidentiality of Covered Information, including safeguards, controls, data retention limits, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Third Party Assessment
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain biennial third-party assessments of its privacy program from a qualified assessor, with the first assessment due within 180 days of the Order's entry, and must submit those assessments to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: One year after entry of the Order and each year thereafter, a senior corporate manager must submit a certification to the FTC confirming compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $1,500,000 to the United States Treasury within 7 days of entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all dominion and control over funds paid; the facts in the Complaint are taken as true and cannot be contested in any subsequent civil litigation by the FTC; and Defendant must provide its Taxpayer Identification Number.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Defendant must deliver copies of the Order and obtain signed acknowledgments from its principals, officers, directors, and certain employees and service providers.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must file compliance reports with the FTC one year after entry of the Order and annually thereafter, and must notify the FTC of changes to its corporate structure within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order, retaining each such record for 5 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Commission Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through various means including inspections, interviews, and discovery.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: This Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Ban on Sale or Disclosure of Browsing Information
provisions.summary: Respondents are prohibited from selling, licensing, or otherwise disclosing Browsing Information to Third Parties for Advertising Purposes, and from using Browsing Information for Advertising Purposes without Affirmative Express Consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibited Misleading Representations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent the purpose of their collection or use of Covered Information, the extent to which it is aggregated or anonymized, or the extent to which they collect, use, disclose, or maintain Covered Information or protect its privacy and security.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Respondents must delete all Jumpshot Data and any derived models, algorithms, or software within 20 days, instruct Third Parties to do the same, and provide sworn written statements confirming deletion to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notice to Users
provisions.summary: Within 28 days of the effective date, Respondents must post a notice on their websites, notify users within affected Avast Products, and send the FTC-mandated Exhibit A Notice by email to affected users.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of the effective date, each Respondent that collects, uses, discloses, or maintains Covered Information must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program, including documentation, board reporting, designated personnel, risk assessments, safeguards, training, and ongoing monitoring.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their Privacy Program, covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with results submitted to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with third-party Assessors by providing all relevant information, disclosing network and IT asset details, and not misrepresenting any material facts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Beginning one year after issuance and each year thereafter, Respondents must submit to the FTC a sworn senior officer certification of compliance with the Privacy Program, and publish all certifications on their website.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondents must pay $16,500,000 to the FTC within 9 days of the effective date of this Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondents relinquish all rights to transferred assets, agree that Complaint facts will be taken as true in any enforcement litigation, and acknowledge how unspent funds will be handled and the consequences of default.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, file notices of material changes within 14 days, notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filings, and submit all materials via the specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 10 years after the issuance date and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting records, personnel records, advertising materials, privacy representations, Assessment materials, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting compliance reports and records, communicating directly with Respondents, interviewing personnel, and using other lawful investigative means.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of this Order in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresenting Effectiveness of Information Removal Service
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent, in any manner, the effectiveness of PrivacyLock or any similar service that allows consumers to remove publicly available information from respondents' search results, websites, or advertisements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Representations Without Clear Disclosure of Material Limitations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not make any representation about the effectiveness of PrivacyLock or a similar service unless they clearly and prominently disclose all material limitations, including duration limits and circumstances under which information will not be removed or will reappear.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Refunds and Accounting
provisions.summary: Respondents must issue full refunds to all consumers who paid for PrivacyLock, provide notice via email and on their website, and submit a complete accounting to the Commission of all refunds paid and amounts not refunded, with any unrefunded amounts remitted to the U.S. Treasury as disgorgement.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must retain and make available to the FTC for five years after the last dissemination of any covered representation: all advertisements, consumer complaints and refund requests with responses, and all records necessary to demonstrate compliance with the order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Delivery and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: For five years from issuance, respondents must deliver a copy of the order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers engaged in related conduct, and obtain signed, dated acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the FTC at least 30 days before any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, such as dissolution, merger, sale, subsidiary creation, bankruptcy filing, or name/address change, with notices sent by overnight courier or first-class mail with simultaneous email.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must each file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of the order, and submit additional written reports within 10 days of any written request from the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on March 14, 2031, or 20 years from the most recent date a federal court complaint alleging a violation of the order is filed, whichever is later, with specific carve-outs for provisions with shorter terms and for respondents not named as defendants.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Against COPPA Violations
provisions.summary: Defendant is enjoined from violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule in connection with any website or online service directed to children.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Children's Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is enjoined from making any misrepresentation concerning the collection, use, disclosure, or deletion of children's personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must delete all personal information collected and maintained in violation of the Rule from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy
provisions.summary: Defendant must place a clear and conspicuous notice on websites directed to children that provides a hyperlink to FTC privacy tips for 5 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $250,000 to the United States within 5 days of receipt of notice of entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain acknowledgments of receipt of the Order from itself and deliver the Order to specified personnel and entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must make timely submissions to the Commission including a comprehensive compliance report 180 days after entry of the Order and change notifications for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order, and retain each such record for 5 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor compliance with this Order through various means including requests for reports, depositions, document production, interviews, and other lawful discovery methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Privacy Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent the extent to which they maintain privacy or confidentiality of consumer data, including collection, use, disclosure, or sharing practices, or the extent to which software code determines whether a user has previously visited a webpage.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Data Deletion and Non-Use Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondents must not use, disclose, sell, rent, lease, or transfer any information collected using history sniffing, and must permanently delete or destroy all such information within five days, providing written confirmation to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondents must maintain and make available to the FTC records including consumer complaints, compliance records, and publicly disseminated documents related to data collection and privacy practices for specified retention periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant personnel for three years, securing signed acknowledgments of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Change in Corporate Status Notification
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the Commission at least thirty days prior to any change in corporate structure or status that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy, or change of name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a true and accurate compliance report with the Commission within ninety days after service of the order and submit additional reports upon request within ten days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on March 13, 2033, or twenty years from the most recent date a complaint alleging violation is filed in federal court, whichever comes later, subject to specified exceptions and conditions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: No Misrepresentations About Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the security, privacy, or confidentiality of consumer data.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition on the Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from selling, transferring, or otherwise disclosing consumers' Sensitive Personal Information to any person, with limited exceptions for payment processing with express consumer consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Consumer Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide consumer information to the FTC upon request, is prohibited from using or disclosing consumer information obtained prior to the Order, and must destroy all such consumer information within 30 days of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must acknowledge receipt of the Order, deliver copies to relevant personnel and business entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn compliance report one year after the Order, provide notice of material changes within 14 days for 20 years, notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all sworn filings in the required format and manner.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create specified records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years, covering consumer consent records, accounting records, personnel records, complaints, compliance documentation, and marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has broad authority to monitor Defendant's compliance, including demanding information, conducting depositions, using discovery procedures, communicating directly with Defendant's personnel, and employing undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b) and Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating FTC Order
provisions.summary: Defendant and all persons acting in concert with it are permanently enjoined from violating, directly or indirectly, any provision of the 2012 FTC Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty Judgment
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $500,000 is entered against Defendant, which must be paid within 7 days of entry of this Order via electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Evaluation of Informed User Consent to Data Collection and Use
provisions.summary: Before making any Targeting Tool available to consumers, Defendant must obtain an evaluation and report from a qualified, FTC-approved third-party professional certifying compliance with the FTC Order's disclosure and consent requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Assessment of Targeting Tool
provisions.summary: For any assessment conducted under Section VI of the FTC Order, Defendant must obtain advance written approval from the FTC Associate Director for Enforcement for the assessment's scope and design.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Removal of the RewardU Toolbar and Associated Cookies
provisions.summary: Defendant must permanently expire all RewardU-related cookies and notify all affected consumers to uninstall the toolbar and delete associated cookies within 30 days of entry of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to all principals and relevant personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of the Order, and for 20 years thereafter must submit sworn compliance notices within 14 days of certain changes in structure or contact information, and within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, including compliance records, accounting records, and personnel records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Plaintiff and the FTC have broad rights to monitor Defendant's compliance, including demanding additional reports, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendant, and using undercover means, all without further court order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Disclosure and Consent for Targeting Tool
provisions.summary: Respondent must clearly and prominently disclose all types of data collected and how it is used, and must obtain express affirmative consent from consumers prior to enabling any Targeting Tool, including for previously installed TurboSaver Toolbars before making material changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Notification to Affected Consumers
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify Affected Consumers about the Personalized Offers feature, the data collected, and how to disable and uninstall the TurboSaver Toolbar through website posting, direct consumer inquiries, and direct notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Deletion of Collected Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must delete or destroy all Collected Information in its custody or control within 5 days of service of the FTC Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available for FTC inspection, for 5 years after the last dissemination of any covered representation, all advertisements, supporting materials, contradicting evidence, and Order acknowledgments; and for 3 years after each assessment, all materials used to prepare that assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Cooperation with the Commission
provisions.summary: Respondent must cooperate in good faith with the FTC in connection with this action or any related subsequent investigation, appearing for interviews, conferences, discovery, and proceedings as reasonably requested.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of the FTC Order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and relevant managers, and obtain a signed and dated acknowledgment from each recipient.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting / Notification of Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, sale, merger, creation or dissolution of subsidiaries, bankruptcy filing, or change in name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report within 60 days of service of the FTC Order and submit additional written reports within 10 days of the FTC's written request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Order Duration / Termination
provisions.summary: The FTC Order terminates on December 31, 2031, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondents are permanently restrained from violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA), 16 C.F.R. Part 312, including failing to establish reasonable procedures to protect the confidentiality, security, and integrity of children's Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in or Compliance with Privacy Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, in any manner, the extent to which it participates in, complies with, or is certified under any privacy or security program sponsored by a government or self-regulatory organization, including EU-U.S. Privacy Shield, Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield, and APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Requirement to Meet Continuing Obligations Under Privacy Shield
provisions.summary: Respondent must either affirm to the Department of Commerce that it will continue applying Privacy Shield principles (or use another EU-law-authorized means) to personal information received during participation, or return or delete that information — both within ten days of the Order's effective date.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within ten days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel within specified timeframes, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within thirty days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial sworn compliance report within 60 days, submit sworn notices of changes to contact information or corporate structure within 14 days, and submit notice of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, all in accordance with specified submission requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for ten years after the Order's issuance date and retain each record for five years, including accounting records, personnel records, compliance records, and copies of representations subject to the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance through written requests for reports and records, direct communications and interviews with affiliated persons, and other lawful investigative means including undercover inquiries.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on March 16, 2040, or twenty years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation is filed in federal court, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting with them are permanently enjoined from failing to provide direct notice to parents, failing to post required privacy links, failing to obtain Verifiable Parental Consent, retaining children's data longer than necessary, and violating the COPPA Rule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Children's Personal Information Previously Collected
provisions.summary: Defendants must refrain from using previously collected children's data without parental consent, destroy such data within specified deadlines, submit sworn statements confirming destruction, delete Affected Work Product, and maintain a compliant data retention schedule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $1.5 million is entered against Defendants jointly and severally, to be paid within 7 days of entry of this Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit sworn acknowledgments of receipt of this Order, deliver copies to relevant personnel and entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit annual compliance reports, timely notices of structural or contact changes, bankruptcy notices, and all submissions must be sworn under penalty of perjury and delivered as directed.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for ten years and retain each for five years, covering accounting records, personnel records, compliance records, consumer complaints, communications, and copies of forms collecting children's personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through information requests, depositions, discovery, direct communications, employee interviews, and undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b; Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Injunction Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, as currently promulgated or as modified in the future.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Children's Privacy
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any misrepresentation in a website's privacy policy or elsewhere about the collection, use, or disclosure of children's personal information, or about procedures to maintain its confidentiality, security, or integrity.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy — FTC KidzPrivacy Notice
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must place a clear and conspicuous FTC KidzPrivacy notice in their privacy policy, direct notices to parents, and at each personal information collection point on any child-directed website or online service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $35,000
provisions.summary: Defendants Bigmailbox.com, Inc. and Nolan Quan are jointly and severally required to pay a civil penalty of $35,000 to the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Payment of Civil Penalty — Method and Delivery
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay the $35,000 civil penalty on the date of entry of the Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check payable to the Treasurer of the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Default Interest on Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: If defendants default on payment for more than ten days past the due date, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Deletion of Previously Collected Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must delete all personal information previously collected from children through www.bigmailbox.com prior to entry of the Consent Decree.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide to Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of entry, defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and FTC compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees, obtain signed acknowledgment statements, and within 10 days thereafter submit a signed compliance statement to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide to Future Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide to all future principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees within 30 days of their assuming such position, and maintain copies of signed acknowledgment statements available to the FTC upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Initial Compliance Report
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of entry, defendants must file a written compliance report with the FTC detailing their compliance with the Consent Decree, including registration processes, privacy notices, parental consent methods, and data security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping — Compliance Documents
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must maintain and make available to the FTC within seven days of request print or electronic copies of all documents demonstrating compliance with the Consent Decree, including every information collection form, web page, and representation about data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Business Changes — Bigmailbox.com, Inc.
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change affecting compliance obligations, such as mergers, dissolutions, bankruptcies, or name/address changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Employment Changes — Nolan Quan
provisions.summary: For three years, defendant Nolan Quan must notify the FTC of any discontinuation of his current business or employment, or any new involvement in an Internet-related business involving online collection of personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Numbers
provisions.summary: Defendants are required to furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers to the FTC for use in collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts arising from their government relationship.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Submission Address for Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 12–19 must be sent by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.summary: The Complaint states a claim upon which relief may be granted under COPPA and the FTC Act.

provisions.title: Injunction — Prohibition Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendant and all associated persons are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, directly or through any subsidiary, website, or other device.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy — FTC Privacy Notice
provisions.summary: For five years, defendant must post a clear and conspicuous FTC children's privacy notice (with hyperlink) in its privacy policy, direct notices to parents, and at each location where personal information is collected on children-directed websites.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — Amount
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $35,000 to the United States pursuant to the FTC Act.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against False or Misleading Representations About Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent is prohibited from making any false or misleading representation, express or implied, regarding the collection, use, or disclosure of personally identifiable information from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition on Disclosure of Pre-Order Consumer Information for Marketing
provisions.summary: Respondent must not sell, rent, or disclose to any third party for marketing purposes any personally identifiable information collected from consumers prior to the date of service of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Conditional Prohibition on Disclosure of Post-Order Consumer Information for Marketing
provisions.summary: Respondent must not sell, rent, or disclose post-Order consumer information for marketing purposes unless it first provided the merchant customer a clear written notice and obtained written certification, or provided a clear disclosure directly to consumers about Respondent's data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Disgorgement Payment
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $9,101.63 to the United States Treasury as disgorgement within five days of service of this Order, with interest accruing on any default balance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC for five years all documents demonstrating compliance with the Order, including privacy statements, merchant notices and certifications, and records of third-party disclosures.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of the Order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities, and obtain signed, dated acknowledgments of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this Order, including dissolution, sale, merger, bankruptcy filings, or name/address changes.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they collect, use, maintain, disclose, or delete Covered Information, or the extent to which their Location Data is Deidentified.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibitions on the Use, Sale, or Disclosure of Sensitive Location Data
provisions.summary: Respondents must not sell, license, transfer, share, disclose, or otherwise use Sensitive Location Data associated with identified Sensitive Locations, subject to narrow exceptions for data conversion or direct consumer relationships with Affirmative Express Consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Sensitive Location Data Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a Sensitive Location Data Program within 180 days, including documented policies, a senior officer responsible, biannual assessments, technical controls, and timely deletion of Sensitive Location Data.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Other Location Data Obligations
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish within 180 days policies, procedures, and technical measures to prevent recipients of their Location Data from associating it with LGBTQ+ service locations, political/social demonstrations, or individuals' private residences, including contractual prohibitions, marking techniques, compliance assessments, and termination of non-compliant relationships.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Third-Party Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of determining a Third-Party Incident has occurred, Respondents must submit a report to the Commission including details about the incident, affected data, number of consumers affected, and remediation steps taken.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Limitations on Collection, Use, Maintenance, and Disclosure of Location Data
provisions.summary: Respondents must not collect or use Location Data where a consumer has opted out via OS privacy settings without documented consent, must not collect Location Data without documented prior consent within 90 days, and must provide Clear and Conspicuous quarterly reminders via Respondents' App.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Supplier Assessment Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must implement a Supplier Assessment Program within 90 days to ensure consumer consent for Location Data collection, including documented procedures, initial and annual assessments of third-party suppliers, consent records, and ceasing use of non-consented Location Data.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Disclosures to Consumers
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide consumers a Clear and Conspicuous means to request the identity of entities to whom their Location Data has been disclosed, or alternatively offer a deletion mechanism with confirmation to recipients within 90 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Withholding and Withdrawing Consent
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide a simple, easily-located means for consumers to withdraw consent for Location Data collection and must not unreasonably limit consumers' ability to withhold or withdraw consent through degradation of product quality or functionality.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Obligations When Consent is Withdrawn
provisions.summary: Respondents must cease collecting Location Data associated with a specific app and device within 15 days after receiving notice that a consumer has withdrawn their consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Location Data Deletion Requests
provisions.summary: Respondents must implement and maintain a simple, easily-located means for consumers to request deletion of their Location Data and must delete such data within 30 days of receiving a request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Retention Limits
provisions.summary: Respondents must publish a Clear and Conspicuous data retention schedule on their website within 60 days, submit it to the Commission, and update it prior to collecting any new types of consumer information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion
provisions.summary: Respondents must delete Historic Location Data collected through their apps and SDK within 60 days (or obtain Affirmative Express Consent or Deidentify within 90 days), notify customers who received such data, and delete all Data Products within 90 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program within 60 days, including written documentation, board reporting, a designated coordinator, annual risk assessments, safeguards, annual employee training, and regular program evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit sworn acknowledgments of receipt of this Order within 10 days, deliver copies to key personnel within 10 days (and to future personnel before they assume responsibilities) for 5 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit an annual compliance report one year after the issuance date, provide notices within 14 days of any changes to contact points or corporate structure, and submit notice within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 5 years after the issuance date, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, representations about data practices, consent records, reminder records, supplier assessment records, sensitive location program records, deletion request records, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 14 days, communicating directly with and interviewing affiliated individuals, and using other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation with FTC
provisions.summary: Defendants must cooperate in good faith with the FTC in connection with this action or related investigations, including appearing for interviews, discovery, and testimony upon written request.
