provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of the Order, submit compliance notices within 14 days of specified changes for 10 years, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and follow prescribed submission procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57(b); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for 10 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, covering accounting records, compliance records, consumer complaints, and copies of data collection forms and privacy representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57(b); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance by requesting reports, conducting depositions, obtaining discovery, communicating directly with Defendants and their personnel, and using other lawful investigative means.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57(b); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57(b); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Information Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner the purposes, consumer controls, compliance program participation, or extent of collection and protection related to Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of filing, Respondent must instruct any Third Party that received Health Information from Respondent belonging to any Covered App User to destroy such information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice to Users
provisions.summary: Within 14 days of filing, Respondent must post the required notice Clearly and Conspicuously on its website and email it to all Covered App Users, with no additional materials included.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Before disclosing any consumer's Health Information to any Third Party, Respondent must provide clear and conspicuous disclosure of the categories, identities, and purposes of disclosure, and obtain affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Review
provisions.summary: Within 180 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must obtain an independent third-party Compliance Review of its privacy practices against the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield Principles, and submit it to the Commission within 10 days of completion.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation with Compliance Reviewer
provisions.summary: Respondent must disclose all material facts to the Compliance Reviewer and must not misrepresent any fact material to the Reviewer's determination about Respondent's privacy practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Certification
provisions.summary: Within 180 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must submit a senior management certification to the Commission confirming establishment and maintenance of Order requirements and absence of known material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of discovering a Covered Incident, Respondent must submit a report to the Commission detailing the date, facts, scope, number of affected consumers, remediation steps, and any notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies to key personnel for 5 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from recipients within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must file sworn compliance reports annually for 5 years starting 60 days after issuance, submit notices of structural or contact changes within 14 days, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all required materials electronically or by overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create certain records for 20 years and retain each for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance documentation, advertising materials, privacy-related representations, and Compliance Review materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission may monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC website and will terminate 20 years from issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date a federal complaint alleging a violation is filed, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Ban on Disclosure of Health Information for Advertising Purposes
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disclosing Health Information to Third Parties for Advertising Purposes, with limited exceptions for analytics, direct consumer communications, and contextual advertising.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from misrepresenting the extent to which it collects, uses, discloses, or protects Covered Information, consumer privacy controls, or the purposes for which Covered Information is used.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Disclosure of Health Information Without Affirmative Express Consent and Notice
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disclosing Health Information to Third Parties for non-Advertising Purposes without first obtaining Affirmative Express Consent, and must provide Clear and Conspicuous notice of the categories of Health Information disclosed and the identities and purposes of Third Parties.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Health Breach Notifications
provisions.summary: Following discovery of a Breach of Security of Unsecured PHR Identifiable Health Information, Defendant must notify affected individuals, the FTC, and prominent media outlets (if 500+ residents affected), within prescribed timeframes and with prescribed content and format.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Notice to Users
provisions.summary: Within 28 days of Order entry, Defendant must post a mandated notice on its websites and mobile application home screen, leave it in place for 6 months, and email it to Covered Users who used Premom from November 2017 to August 2022.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Deletion of Covered Information
provisions.summary: Within 45 days of Order entry, Defendant must identify all Third Parties that received Covered Information, notify them of the FTC allegations, instruct specific Third Parties (Jiguang, Umeng, AppsFlyer, Google) to delete Covered Information and Health Information of Covered Users, and provide all related instructions and confirmations to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy and Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of Order entry, Defendant must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy and information security program covering documentation, governance, risk assessment, safeguards (including data inventory, access controls, training, data retention, and SDK audits), periodic evaluation, service provider oversight, and Clear and Conspicuous disclosures to consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Privacy and Information Security Assessment by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain an initial third-party assessment and biennial assessments for 20 years from a qualified, independent Assessor with at least 3 years of experience, covering the effectiveness of the Program and any gaps; assessments must be completed within 90 days after each reporting period and submitted to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Cooperation with Assessor(s)
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide Assessors with all relevant information and materials, disclose all material facts, and not misrepresent any fact material to the Assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: One year after Order entry and each year thereafter for 20 years, Defendant must provide the FTC with a sworn certification confirming compliance, disclosing any uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of discovering a Covered Incident, Defendant must submit a report to the FTC including date, description, number of affected consumers, remediation steps, and any notices sent (unless the incident is a Section IV Breach of Security requiring separate notification).
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $100,000 is entered against Defendant, payable to the U.S. Treasury within 7 days of Order entry by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all rights in transferred assets, facts from the Complaint may be used in future enforcement proceedings, and Defendant's tax identification numbers may be used for collecting delinquent amounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgements
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to all principals, officers, managers, and relevant employees within 14 days (and to future personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: One year after Order entry, Defendant must submit a sworn compliance report identifying contacts, businesses, and activities, and describing compliance with each Section; for 20 years, must submit compliance notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes and notify the FTC within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specified records for 20 years (with a 5-year retention period for each record), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, Health Information disclosures, App Event disclosures, marketing materials, Assessment-related materials, law enforcement communications, and all records demonstrating compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance by requesting additional reports and records (within 14 days of written request), communicating directly with Defendant, interviewing affiliated persons, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant and those acting in concert with it are permanently enjoined from failing to provide required direct and online notices to parents, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting children's personal information, retaining children's personal information longer than necessary, and violating the COPPA Rule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Required Notice to Adults
provisions.summary: Defendant must send the Xbox Platform Notice and the 'Microsoft's Xbox Parental Controls and Family Settings' email notice to every Adult Microsoft Account not associated with a Child Microsoft Account, within 45 days of entry of the Order (180 days for non-U.S. accounts).
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Personal Information Previously Collected from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant must seek verifiable parental consent for existing Child Microsoft Accounts, suspend collection and use of their data if consent is not obtained, delete unconsented data within one year of the Account Suspension Date, and submit a sworn written report on outcomes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Data Retention
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish a system to delete within two weeks any Personal Information collected for purposes of obtaining parental consent (if consent is not given), and must maintain a publicly available retention schedule for Personal Information collected through Child Microsoft Accounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Requirement to Notify Third Parties When Disclosing Personal Information Collected from a Child
provisions.summary: Within 120 days of entry of the Order, Defendant must indicate to video game publishers (e.g., via API) whenever it discloses Personal Information from a Child Microsoft Account that the user is under age 13.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Mandated Data Documentation
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of entry of the Order, Defendant must internally document the decision to collect, use, disclose, or maintain each Personal Information data field from Child Microsoft Accounts, including purpose, segmentation controls, retention limits, deletion means, safeguards against unauthorized sharing, and access controls.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Registration Requirement
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain the age of users during account registration for a Covered Service and must provide Clear and Conspicuous notice about creating child accounts and parental controls during the registration process.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $20,000,000 is entered against Defendant, payable to the U.S. Treasury within 7 days of entry of the Order, with Defendant relinquishing all rights to the transferred assets.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver copies to all principals, officers, managers, and relevant employees within 7 days (and to new personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after entry of the Order, submit sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes for 10 years, notify the Commission within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing, and follow specified submission procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create specified records for each Covered Service for 10 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, and copies of collection forms and privacy representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through written requests for reports, depositions, document production, direct communications with Defendant and its personnel, and other lawful investigative means including undercover contacts.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), and 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Ban on Disclosure of Health Information for Advertising Purposes
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from disclosing Health Information to Third Parties for Advertising Purposes, including advertising, marketing, or promoting products or services through third-party platforms.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Requirement to Obtain Affirmative Express Consent for Any Other Disclosure of Health Information
provisions.summary: Before disclosing any consumer's Health Information to any Third Party, Defendant must first obtain the relevant consumer's Affirmative Express Consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from misrepresenting its data collection, use, and disclosure practices, including misrepresentations about HIPAA compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Data Deletion
provisions.summary: Defendant must identify all Third Parties that received Covered Information without consent, notify them, instruct them to delete that information, and cease further disclosures to them pending confirmation of receipt.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Notice to Covered Users
provisions.summary: Defendant must email all Covered Users a court-mandated notice (Exhibit A) within 14 days of the effective date of the Order, without including any other materials with the notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Defendant must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive privacy program within 60 days, including written documentation, risk assessments, safeguards, employee training, data retention policies, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Privacy Assessments by a Third-Party Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Privacy Program, covering the first year and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, with assessments completed within 60 days after each reporting period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Cooperation with Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendant must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing all Covered Information in its custody, and not misrepresenting any material facts to the Assessor.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide annual certifications from a senior corporate manager to the Commission for 10 years, attesting to compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a report to the Commission within 30 days of discovering a Covered Incident, including the date, description, number of consumers affected, remediation steps taken, and any notices sent to consumers or government entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty and Suspension
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $2,500,000 is entered against Defendant but suspended based on Defendant's financial representations; the suspension will be lifted if Defendant is found to have made material misstatements in its financial disclosures.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all right and title to assets transferred under the Order; the Complaint's allegations may be taken as true in subsequent litigation; the civil penalty is non-dischargeable in bankruptcy; and Defendant's Taxpayer Identification Numbers may be used for collection purposes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must acknowledge receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver copies to all relevant personnel within 7 days (and to future personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018 (OARFPA), 15 U.S.C. § 45d

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit an annual compliance report one year after entry, provide timely notices of any changes in contact information or corporate structure for 10 years, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all filings under penalty of perjury via the designated email address.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping

Part 312

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Use of Previously Collected Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant must refrain from using previously collected Children's Personal Information without consent, destroy existing non-consented data within 60 days, provide sworn written statements to the Commission within 90 days, delete Affected Work Product within 90 days, and maintain a data retention schedule.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: A $6 million civil penalty judgment is entered against Defendant but suspended based on Defendant's sworn financial statements; the suspension will be lifted and the full amount become due if Defendant is found to have made material misstatements in its Financial Attestations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendant relinquishes all rights to assets transferred under this Order, stipulates that Complaint facts will be taken as true in future enforcement proceedings, and acknowledges that its Taxpayer Identification Numbers may be used for collecting on any delinquent amounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 7 days, deliver copies to all principals, officers, key employees, and agents within 7 days (and before others assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a comprehensive sworn compliance report one year after entry of this Order, file sworn compliance notices within 14 days of any structural or contact changes for 10 years, notify the Commission within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing, and submit all required sworn statements in the prescribed form and to the prescribed address.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create specific records for 10 years and retain each for 5 years, covering accounting records, personnel records, compliance documentation, consumer complaints, consent records, and copies of data collection forms and privacy representations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through document requests, depositions, discovery, direct communications, employee interviews, and undercover methods, with Defendant required to respond within 14 days of written requests.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting its privacy and security practices, compliance program memberships (including HIPAA and Privacy Shield), HIPAA regulatory status, and the independent status of endorsers or reviewers of its products.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 7(a) of the Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003 (CAN-SPAM Act), 15 U.S.C. § 7706(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations Regarding Online Collection of Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must not make any misrepresentation in connection with online collection of personal information from children and/or consumers ages 13–17, including about anonymity, promised products/services, prize eligibility, or collection and use practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Collecting Personal Information Without Parental Permission
provisions.summary: Respondent must not collect personal information from a child at a website directed to children (or any site where respondent has actual knowledge it is collecting from a child) when respondent has actual knowledge the child lacks parental permission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Affirmative Obligation to Provide Clear and Prominent Privacy Notice
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide clear and prominent notice of its practices regarding collection and use of personal information from children, including what is collected, how it is used, disclosure practices, and a means for parents to access or delete their child's information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Affirmative Obligation to Obtain Verifiable Parental Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain a procedure to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting, using, or disclosing personal information from children online.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Deletion of Previously Collected Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must delete all personal information previously collected from children prior to the date of service of this order from its websites directed to children and any commercial websites where it has actual knowledge it collected personal information from a child.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: COPPA Compliance as Deemed Compliance
provisions.summary: After the effective date of COPPA and any FTC regulations or guides thereunder, compliance with that statute and its regulations shall be deemed compliance with the definitions section and Parts II, III, and IV of this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC upon request records evidencing compliance with Parts III–V, including copies of web pages and information collection forms, and all materials evidencing verifiable parental consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities — current personnel within 30 days, future personnel within 30 days of assuming their position.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolution, sale, merger, bankruptcy, or name/address change.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 60 days of service of this order and at such other times as the FTC may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on August 12, 2019, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or FTC files a federal court complaint alleging any violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction — COPPA Rule Compliance
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, as it may be amended.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Consumer Education — FTC Privacy Notice on Child-Directed Sites
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must post a bold, conspicuous FTC privacy hyperlink in their privacy policy, parent notice, and at each personal-information collection point on any child-directed website or online service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Consumer Education — OnGuardOnline Safety Tips on Blog Hosting Service
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must place a conspicuous OnGuardOnline social-networking safety-tips hyperlink on the homepage(s) and privacy notice(s) of any blog hosting service they operate.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $1,000,000
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay a $1,000,000 civil penalty jointly and severally: $600,000 within five business days of entry, then two $200,000 installments (plus interest) due at six and twelve months from entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Default in Payment
provisions.summary: If any payment is in default for ten days beyond its due date, the entire remaining unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Within five days of entry, defendants must delete all personal information collected and maintained in violation of the COPPA Rule through the date of entry.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Distribution of Order and Compliance Guide — Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Within thirty days of entry, defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and COPPA compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, agents, and representatives, obtain signed acknowledgments, and submit a compliance statement to the Commission within ten days thereafter.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Distribution of Order and Compliance Guide — Future Personnel
provisions.summary: For five years from entry, defendants must provide the Consent Decree and compliance guide to all future principals, officers, directors, managers, relevant employees, agents, and representatives within thirty days of their assuming such position, obtain signed and dated acknowledgments, and maintain those records for Commission inspection upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For three years, individual defendants must notify the Commission of changes in address, employment, ownership, name, and corporate structure. Beginning sixty days after entry, all defendants must submit sworn written compliance reports whenever the FTC reasonably requires, detailing registration practices, privacy notices, parental consent procedures, and data protection measures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: For five years from entry, defendants must maintain and make available to the FTC (within fourteen days of a written request) print or electronic copies of all documents demonstrating compliance, including acknowledgments, reports, web page copies with URLs, and all materials related to the collection, use, and disclosure of children's personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Provision of Taxpayer Identifying Numbers
provisions.summary: Defendants must furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers (SSN or EIN) to the FTC pursuant to 31 U.S.C. § 7701 for use in collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts owed to the government.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter to allow any party to seek further orders for interpretation, modification, enforcement, or punishment of violations of the Consent Decree.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a), and 57b

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For three years, Defendants must deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and business entities and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of the Order within five business days of its entry by the Court.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Provision of Taxpayer Identifying Numbers
provisions.summary: Corporate Defendant must furnish its taxpayer identifying number (employer identification number) to the FTC for purposes of collecting and reporting any delinquent amounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for the purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Privacy Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy and confidentiality of covered information, or its participation in privacy or security compliance programs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program reasonably designed to address privacy risks and protect the privacy and confidentiality of covered information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Third-Party Privacy Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial privacy assessments from a qualified, independent third-party professional covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various records including privacy-related statements, consumer complaints, law enforcement communications, compliance documents, and assessment materials for periods of five years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees with supervisory responsibilities, and any business entity resulting from structural changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least thirty days prior to any change in the corporation that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, bankruptcy, or change in corporate name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial compliance report with the Commission within sixty days after service of the order and submit additional reports within ten days of request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 30, 2032, or twenty years from the most recent date that the United States or the Commission files a complaint in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained and enjoined from violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, including failing to provide notice to parents, failing to post online notices, and failing to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting personal information from children.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from disclosing, using, or benefitting from personal information collected from children prior to entry of this Order, and must delete all such information within ten days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment for Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $300,000 to the United States Treasury within seven days of entry of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain and submit acknowledgments of receipt of this Order from itself, from specified personnel, and from any business entity resulting from structural changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit compliance reports and notices to the Commission, including an annual compliance report one year after entry of the Order and notices of changes in structure or bankruptcy within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain specified records for ten years after entry of the Order, with each record retained for five years, including all compliance records, consumer complaints, and documents relating to personal information collection practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through various means including requesting additional reports, depositions, document production, interviews, and posing as consumers or other entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Consumer Control and Notice
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the options through which consumers can exercise control over data collection or the extent to which consumers will receive notice about data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC various records related to compliance, representations, and consumer complaints for specified periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future personnel with relevant responsibilities and obtain signed acknowledgments for 10 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any corporate changes that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file compliance reports with the Commission detailing compliance with this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on August 28, 2035, or 20 years from the most recent date the U.S. or FTC files a complaint alleging violation of the order, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from withholding customer information needed for Commission redress administration and from disclosing or misusing personal information obtained prior to entry of this Order, except for current customers in compliance with Section I.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security and Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they protect the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of Personal Information, including representations about collection/use/sharing, consumer control, and security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notice and Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Prior to collecting or disclosing any Covered Information, Respondents must clearly and conspicuously disclose the categories of information collected, identity of third-party recipients, and all purposes for collection/use/sharing, and must obtain the consumer's affirmative express consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Each Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and new business entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports and timely notices of material changes (including structural changes, personnel changes for Individual Respondent, and bankruptcy filings) to the Commission, all sworn under penalty of perjury.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain specified records for 20 years after issuance (retaining each for at least 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, representations about Personal Information, law enforcement communications, and assessment materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent-affiliated persons, and using any other lawful means including undercover investigation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates on September 6, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging any violation of this Order in federal court, whichever comes later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Designating Content on the YouTube Service as Directed to Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from failing to develop and maintain a system for Channel Owners to designate content as directed to Children, and from failing to provide annual COPPA training for personnel managing Channel Owner relationships.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Collection of Personal Information from Children
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from failing to provide direct notice to parents, failing to post a prominent privacy notice link, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, and from violating the COPPA Rule, in connection with operating a Website or Online Service Directed to Children on the YouTube Service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Use of Previously Collected Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must refrain from disclosing, using, or benefitting from Personal Information previously collected from users of Content designated as directed to Children, within 90 days of the Compliance Date, with an exception for government-required disclosures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty and Other Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Defendants are ordered to pay $136,000,000 to the FTC and $34,000,000 to the State of New York as civil penalties and damages, both within 30 days of entry of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to transferred assets, agree that Complaint facts may be used in future proceedings, and must submit their Taxpayer Identification Numbers to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit sworn acknowledgments of receipt of the Order, deliver copies to key personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit an annual compliance report one year after the Compliance Date, timely notices of structural or contact changes for 10 years, bankruptcy notices within 14 days, and all sworn submissions must comply with specific formatting and delivery requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendants must create specified records for ten years after entry of the Order and retain each record for five years, covering accounting, personnel, compliance, consumer complaints, privacy forms, and advertising materials related to the YouTube Service.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)(1), and Sections 1303(c), 1305(a)(1), and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6504(a)(1), and 6505(d)
